sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: Hack has its core foundations on the PHP programming language. It is a dialect of PHP. While docs.hhvm.com is the definitive source of Hack and PHP information, it might be useful to have a quick overview of some topics in one place.

sect1.title: The <?php tag
sect1.para: The first construct to notice is the beginning <?php tag. All PHP files will have this tag to dictate that PHP is about to follow. There is generally no need to end your PHP code with ?>. In fact, for code that is only PHP (i.e., not intermixed with HTML), the accepted coding standard is to require no tag. Omitting the tag prevents unwanted whitespace at the end of files.

sect1.title: Variables
Control Flow
Arrays
sect1.para:
If an array has a mix of explicit and implicit keys, then the next implicit key after the explicit key will be the next greatest integer after the last integer key, starting from 0.
<?php $arr = array("a", "b", 6 =>"c", "d"); echo $arr[0]; // "a" echo $arr[7]; // "d"
Arrays have associated functions such as sort(), count(), shuffle(), array_pop(), etc. Arrays are a big topic. See the section on arrays for more information.

sect1.title: Functions
sect1.para: Functions are declared with the function keyword, a function name with optional arguments and then the function body. Functions have global scope when not declared inside a class.Functions can optionally return a value or object. If there is no return statement in a function, null is implicitly returned back to the caller.

Arguments in functions need not be explicitly typed. Functions can provide type hints for object-type arguments, but not for scalar types like integers and strings (Hack remedies this situation). Also, because of the dynamic nature of PHP, specifying return types for functions is not supported in PHP5 (but is supported in Hack).

sect1.title: Traits
sect1.para: Classes don't have to use all of the methods in a trait; they can just come along for the ride. And, since traits are basically just dropped in pieces of code, $this can be used in a trait definition, and when classes use the trait, $this automatically refers to that class object.

Here are some key points about traits.
Traits can be composed from each other. Classes can use multiple traits. The methods of a trait override inherited methods from a parent class. The methods defined in a class override methods from a trait. Traits can implement interfaces

sect1.title: Closures
sect1.para: Closures (sometimes called anonymous functions) are functions that capture a containing scope and provides access to that scope upon invocation. Closures were added to PHP 5.3. Before delving into an example of a closure, it is useful to trace the history of how functions are able to be defined and used in PHP.

sect2.title: Variable Functions
sect2.para:
<?php
function Hello_varfunc($name) {
  echo "Hello $name";
}

$func = "Hello_varfunc";
echo $func;
echo "\n";
$func("Facebook");

          
        
        Here we have a varialbe called $func that is assigned a string with the same variable name as a function. $func can be used as a string or, by wrapping parenthesis, it can be used as a shorthand to the function it is named after.

sect2.title: Anonymous Functions
sect2.para: create_function() is not an ideal way of creating anonymous functions. One particular reason is that passing strings around as functions are at best error-prone and at worst dangerous. Another reason is that memory leaks may occur when creating functions from strings over and over again as these may not be garbage collected correctly.
